title: Highlights from a Weekend in Berlin
name: Highlights from a Weekend in Berlin

properties.name: Cafe Am Neuen See for beer and a pizza
properties.description: Posted by Despitz Lichtensteinallee, BerlinBeer Garden and restaurant overlooking a small lake in central Berlin.

properties.name: Cafes and art galleries along Augustrasse
properties.description: Posted by Despitz

properties.name: Gemaldegalerie for 16th-18th century European art (Holbein, Gainsborough, Rembrant, Caravaggio)
properties.description: Posted by Despitz Stauffenbergstrasse 40, Berlin

properties.name: Hackesche Hofe for shopping, lunch and a coffee
properties.description: Posted by Despitz  Rosenthalerstraße 40, Berlin The Economist: "To catch a slice of the new, cool Berlin, head east to the bustling Hackescher Markt area in Mitte. Here, old tenement blocks, the pre-war homes of the Jewish community, have received a new lease on life and the area is brimming with contemporary art galleries, designer boutiques, chic restaurants and bars. A visit might start at the Hackesche Höfe, a restored complex of art-nouveau lofts housing shops and restaurants, a cinema and a cabaret theatre. For a pre-dinner cocktail, you might head to the nearby Riva Bar."

properties.name: Jewish Museum
properties.description: Posted by Despitz Lindenstraße 9-14, 10969 Berlin

properties.name: Lounging at a beach cafe along the Spree
properties.description: Posted by Despitz

properties.name: Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe
properties.description: Posted by DespitzWikipedia: "The Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe (German: Denkmal für die ermordeten Juden Europas), also known as the Holocaust Memorial (German: Holocaust-Mahnmal), is a memorial in Berlin to the Jewish victims of the Holocaust, designed by architect Peter Eisenman and engineers Buro Happold."

properties.name: Prenzlauer Berg for brunch, shopping and Saturday market
properties.description: Posted by Despitz Kollwitzplatz, Berlin, GermanyCheck out the Thursday/Saturday market in Kollwitzplatz, and the cafes and boutique shops on the surrounding streets, a bit off the beaten track.

properties.name: Tacheles for a late-night drink
properties.description: Posted by Despitz The New York Times (December, 2006): "Few streets have mutated as much as Oranienburger Strasse, the spine of Mitte. A squatters’ row as recently as the late 1990s, the street is now littered with bars and tourist traps that recall Bleecker Street on amateur nights. For a glimpse of Berlin’s quickly fading underbelly, grab a beer at the Tacheles art house (No. 54-56A; 49-30-282-61-85; www.tacheles.de), the ruins of a former department store that feels like the inside of CBGB’s legendary bathroom."
